repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
First time contributing!

The solution has to remove colon (:) from `isfname` on Windows, so I marked the commit with the breaking change flag.
I treated `:\` it as a special case just like `:/`.

# Problem

On Windows, "gf" fails on a filepath that has a line:column suffix. Example:

    E447: Can't find file "src/app/core/services/identity/identity.service.ts:64:23"

# Solution

Colon is not a valid filename character on Windows (except for the drive-letter), so including ":" in 'isfname' is wrong.
Fixes #25160

comment_data.body: "/" is usually, internally, understood to mean "any valid path separate" in most contexts. Is the comment change actually necessary?

comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -30,6 +30,10 @@ if exists('s:did_load')
   set viewoptions&
   set viewoptions+=options
   set switchbuf=
+  if has('win32')
+    " set 'isfname' as old win32 default value
+    set isfname=@,48-57,/,\,.,-,_,+,,,#,$,%,{,},[,],:,@-@,!,~,=

comment_data.body:
The news item should give a hint about the meaning of the change, e.g. "File path drive letters are now detected on Windows without needing to explicitly put ':' in 'isfname'." 

Also need to update `:h nvim-defaults`.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -15,6 +15,8 @@ BREAKING CHANGES                                                *news-breaking*
 
 The following changes may require adaptations in user config or plugins.
 
+• colon (:) has been removed from |'isfname'| on Windows.

comment_data.body: I think the comment is there to clarify about the logic that considers ':' even if not in 'isfname'. I thought that it might be useful to add that ':\\' also is checked, but if we want to be very explicit all ':\\', ':/', ':?' and ':#' are actually considered on `path_has_drive_letter` function.
Note that this comment was originally referring to URLs.
Yes but the logic was exclusively for URLs, now it also considers drives

```suggestion
• Windows file path drive letters are now detected even if ":" is not in 'isfname'.
  The default 'isfname' no longer includes ":".
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -15,6 +15,9 @@ BREAKING CHANGES                                                *news-breaking*
 
 The following changes may require adaptations in user config or plugins.
 
+• File path drive letters are now detected on Windows without needing to
+  explicitly put ':' in 'isfname'.

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
- 'isfname' does not include ":" on Windows. Include ":" in 'isfname' to treat it as part of a filename following the drive letter. 
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -53,6 +53,7 @@ Defaults					            *nvim-defaults*
 - 'hlsearch' is enabled
 - 'include' defaults to "". The C ftplugin sets it to "^\\s*#\\s*include"
 - 'incsearch' is enabled
+- 'isfname' does not include ':' on Windows

@@ -6934,11 +6934,13 @@ char *file_name_in_line(char *line, int col, int options, int count, char *rel_f
   bool is_url = false;
 
   // Search backward for first char of the file name.
-  // Go one char back to ":" before "//" even when ':' is not in 'isfname'.
+  // Go one char back to ":" before "//" or
+  // two chars back to the alphanumeric befor ":\"
+  // even when ':' is not in 'isfname'.

@@ -13,46 +13,46 @@ describe('path collapse', function()
 
   local function join_path(...)
     local pathsep = (is_os('win') and '\\' or '/')
-    return table.concat({...}, pathsep)
+    return table.concat({ ... }, pathsep)
   end
 
   before_each(function()
     targetdir = join_path('test', 'functional', 'fixtures')
     clear()
-    command('edit '..join_path(targetdir, 'tty-test.c'))
+    command('edit ' .. join_path(targetdir, 'tty-test.c'))
     expected_path = eval('expand("%:p")')
   end)
 
   it('with /./ segment #7117', function()
-    command('edit '..join_path(targetdir, '.', 'tty-test.c'))
+    command('edit ' .. join_path(targetdir, '.', 'tty-test.c'))
     eq(expected_path, eval('expand("%:p")'))
   end)
 
   it('with ./ prefix #7117', function()
-    command('edit '..join_path('.', targetdir, 'tty-test.c'))
+    command('edit ' .. join_path('.', targetdir, 'tty-test.c'))
     eq(expected_path, eval('expand("%:p")'))
   end)
 
   it('with ./ prefix, after directory change #7117', function()
-    command('edit '..join_path('.', targetdir, 'tty-test.c'))
+    command('edit ' .. join_path('.', targetdir, 'tty-test.c'))
     command('cd test')
     eq(expected_path, eval('expand("%:p")'))
   end)
 
   it('with /../ segment #7117', function()
-    command('edit '..join_path(targetdir, '..', 'fixtures', 'tty-test.c'))
+    command('edit ' .. join_path(targetdir, '..', 'fixtures', 'tty-test.c'))
     eq(expected_path, eval('expand("%:p")'))
   end)
 
   it('with ../ and different starting directory #7117', function()
     command('cd test')
-    command('edit '..join_path('..', targetdir, 'tty-test.c'))
+    command('edit ' .. join_path('..', targetdir, 'tty-test.c'))
     eq(expected_path, eval('expand("%:p")'))
   end)
 
   it('with ./../ and different starting directory #7117', function()
     command('cd test')
-    command('edit '..join_path('.', '..', targetdir, 'tty-test.c'))
+    command('edit ' .. join_path('.', '..', targetdir, 'tty-test.c'))

comment_data.body:
The "/" case should also be tested on Windows.

Also (in this same test) let's test more variants. Even if the result isn't perfect, just having the explicit test coverage is helpful as documentation of the current state of things.

```lua
insert([[c:/d:/foo/bar.txt]])
command('%delete')
eq(...)
-- UNC path https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/standard/io/file-path-formats
insert([[\\.\UNC\Server\Share\Test\Foo.txt]])
command('%delete')
eq(...)
insert([[//share/c:/foo/bar/]])
command('%delete')
eq(...)
insert([[file://c:/foo/bar]])
command('%delete')
eq(...)
insert([[https://c:/foo/bar]])
command('%delete')
eq(...)
insert([[\foo\bar]])
command('%delete')
eq(...)
insert([[c:\foo\bar]])
command('%delete')
eq(...)
insert([[c:foo\bar]])
command('%delete')
eq(...)
insert([[c:foo/bar]])
command('%delete')
eq(...)
insert([[c:foo]])
command('%delete')
eq(...)
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -67,4 +67,11 @@ describe('file search', function()
     feed('gf')
     eq('filename_with_unicode_ααα', eval('expand("%:t")'))
   end)
+
+  it('considers Windows drives even without ":" in `isfname`', function()
+    command('set isfname-=:')
+    local file_name = is_os('win') and 'C:\\test_file' or 'C:/test_file'

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
  it as part of a filename anywhere in the name (not only the drive letter).
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -53,6 +53,8 @@ Defaults					            *nvim-defaults*
 - 'hlsearch' is enabled
 - 'include' defaults to "". The C ftplugin sets it to "^\\s*#\\s*include"
 - 'incsearch' is enabled
+- 'isfname' does not include ":" on Windows. Include ":" in 'isfname' to treat
+  it as part of a filename following the drive letter.

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
    " Set 'isfname' to Vim default.
```

Though the comment probably could be dropped since the top of this section already mentions "Align Nvim defaults to Vim".
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -26,6 +26,10 @@ if exists('s:did_load')
   set sessionoptions+=options
   set viewoptions+=options
   set switchbuf=
+  if has('win32')
+    " set 'isfname' as old win32 default value

comment_regular_data.body: Try changing 'isfname' to the old value in `test/old/testdir/setup.vim` instead.

> Try changing 'isfname' to the old value in `test/old/testdir/setup.vim` instead.

Instead of updating the `test/old/testdir/test_regexp_utf8.vim`?
The real problem is that colon is not a valid character for path on windows, so adding it in `isfname` is wrong.

![image](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/assets/70452831/a3de5bb0-b5ef-46ed-bce5-61b976f7c023)

![image](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/assets/70452831/ceffb968-1650-4ae4-b60a-951d29b871b1)

_Translates to: **The file name can not contain any of the following characters \ / : * ? " < > |**_

I don't see how my changes affected the failing test now, any idea?

> > Try changing 'isfname' to the old value in `test/old/testdir/setup.vim` instead.
> 
> Instead of updating the `test/old/testdir/test_regexp_utf8.vim`?

Yes.
Done, but it seems other things have crashed now.

> * Please check that the test correctly _fails_ if the code changes are reverted.

I have confirmed that the test fails for Windows if the changes are reverted back, but they still pass on the linux case because the path is identified as an URL.

Is is better to:
- skip the test on Linux?
- `set isfname+=\` on Linux to test `C:\test_file`?

title: fix(gf)!: consider windows drives
